snippet: The Moreland Commission had urged officials to increase disclosure requirements and restrict how campaign funds could be spent. Now, eight months after its work was cut short, little in Albany has changed.
abstract: New York Times investigation finds that questionable financial conduct by elected officials in New York State has continued unabated since Gov Andrew M Cuomo shut down powerful anticorruption panel in March; Moreland Commission's calls to close loopholes, toughen criminal statutes and increase disclosure requirements have gone unheeded by many politicians, who still spend freely and accept huge, murky corporate donations.

byline.original: By THOMAS KAPLAN, WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM and SUSANNE CRAIG

lead_paragraph: The Moreland Commission had urged officials to increase disclosure requirements and restrict how campaign funds could be spent. Now, eight months after its work was cut short, little in Albany has changed.

headline.main: After Ethics Panel’s Shutdown, Loopholes Live On in Albany
